channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Grow More Adept at Defending Against Russian Drones
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said his military began the new year by putting up stiff resistance to Russia’s aerial attacks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing toward Russian forces that were located several kilometers away in the Dontesk region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
item.description: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Richard Pérez-Peña

item.title: Hard-Line Israeli Minister Visits Volatile Jerusalem Holy Site
item.description: Itamar Ben-Gvir, the ultranationalist national security minister, toured the site just days after taking office, drawing a furious reaction from Palestinian leaders.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Visitors walking next to the Dome of the Rock in the compound known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as the Temple Mount, in Jerusalem’s Old City, on Tuesday.

item.title: Japan’s Business Owners Can’t Find Successors. This Man Is Giving His Away.
item.description: An owner’s struggle in Japan’s northern dairy region illuminates one of the potentially devastating economic impacts of an aging society.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hidekazu Yokoyama decided to give away a successful business because his children and employees weren’t interested in running it.

item.title: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
item.description: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American military personnel in February at Mihail Kogalniceanu air base in Romania. The base has long been used to train NATO forces.

item.title: Philippines: Christmas Floods Kill 51 and Strand Thousands
item.description: Heavy rains on Christmas Day killed dozens of people and left thousands displaced. For a deeply Catholic nation, the timing heightened the sense of tragedy.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP), via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A rescue worker helping a resident cross a flooded street on Christmas in Gingoog City, the Philippines.

item.title: Pope Benedict Lies In State, Drawing Thousands of Mourners
item.description: The pope emeritus is lying in state in St. Peter’s Basilica, where some 65,000 mourners, including Roman Catholic faithful and tourists, had paid last respects by Monday evening.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, lying in state in St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City on Monday.

item.title: Benedict’s Death Leaves Catholic Conservatives Bereft
item.description: Even after his resignation as pope, traditionalists invoked Benedict’s name and sought to draw him into internecine ideological wars. Now he is gone.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI celebrating Mass in Washington in 2008.

item.title: A Balkan Leader Gets the Hollywood Treatment, Starring Kevin Spacey
item.description: A director cast the beleaguered actor as Franjo Tudjman, the late Croatian leader, whom some call a patriot and others revile as an ethnonationalist zealot.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Once Upon a Time in Croatia (Movie)
item.media:description: Croatia’s first president, Franjo Tudjman, was described by one historian as “one of the more egregiously unattractive” leaders to emerge in the breakup of Yugoslavia.

item.title: U.K. Rail Strike May Scuttle Post-Holiday Plans to Return to Work
item.description: Public sympathy for striking nurses and other health workers is particularly strong, posing a challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has promised to confront trade unions.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Polling suggests some fall in sympathy for British railroad workers, but also that other strikes, particularly in the health system, have widespread backing.

item.title: Dubai Suspends Alcohol Tax as Regional Competition Heats Up
item.description: Lower-cost liquor could help the emirate keep its edge over neighbors like Saudi Arabia and Qatar as the Middle East’s hub for leisure and business.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A waterfront restaurant in Dubai in 2020. Alcohol is now taxed at 30 percent in the emirate, and individuals need to buy a license to purchase it.

item.title: Climate Activists Find a Way to Get Germany’s Attention: Stop Traffic
item.description: Extreme tactics have pushed the climate crisis to the top of the public discourse but also stirred debate over whether the activists are going too far.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Last Generation climate activists glued to the street in Munich in December. They blocked roads with increasing frequency over the final months of 2022.

item.title: Lula Becomes Brazil’s President, With Bolsonaro in Florida
item.description: Brazil inaugurates its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, on Sunday. Facing investigations, former President Jair Bolsonaro has taken refuge in Orlando.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luis Inacio Lula da Silva , First Lady Rosangela Lula da Silva, Vice president Geraldo Alckmin and his wife Maria Lucia Alckmin riding an open car after being sworn in at the Congress in Brasilia , Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Biofoul’ on Hull Strands Cruise Ship at Sea for 6 Days
item.description: An unidentified organism prompted Australia to block the vessel from docking, forcing passengers to skip a series of port stops.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Viking Orion in Melbourne, Australia, in 2020. Passengers on a holiday cruise have been adrift off the coast of Australia since Dec. 28.

item.title: China Denounces Covid Testing Rules Imposed on Its Travelers
item.description: A government spokeswoman said Beijing would consider reciprocal measures against countries that have sought to limit travelers arriving from China.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Health workers guided travelers from China arriving in South Korea to a Covid testing center at Incheon International Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A major strike on Russian troops.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents after collecting humanitarian aid in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: HIMARS, a US-Made Rocket System, Has Helped Give Ukraine Momentum
item.description: Washington delivered the first batch of truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers, known as HIMARS, in June.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military firing a rocket from a HIMARS near the frontline in the Kherson region in Ukraine.

item.title: The Question of Life Itself
item.description: How people regard the start of life is complicated, polarizing and worthy of exploration.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Bethany Mollenkof for The New York Times
item.media:description: A baby being held.

item.title: 4 Dead in Helicopter Collision in Australia
item.description: The two craft crashed in midair in a tourist area on the Gold Coast, near a theme park. An investigation is underway, with a report expected to take weeks.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The wreckage of two helicopters that collided on Monday in Queensland, Australia. One of the aircraft, at right, was able to land with minor injuries to passengers.

item.title: Dakar Street Style: A Photo Portfolio
item.description: The capital of Senegal has become a fashion center. But photographing stylish people going about their day isn’t as easy as clicking a button.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha
item.media:description: I encountered this local artist walking near the Plage de Virage beach early in the morning on my second day in Dakar. The way that her white dress accentuated the dark tone of her skin as the sun rose created one of the most stunning compositions I’ve seen on the street in some time. Her red hat was the cherry on top.

item.title: How Russia’s War on Ukraine Is Worsening Global Starvation
item.description: Moscow blocks most shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s largest wheat producers, and its attacks on the country’s energy grid also disrupt the flow of food.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: From March to November, Ukraine exported an average of 3.5 million metric tons per month of grains and oilseeds, a drop from five million to seven million metric tons per month before the war.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Lula is now the president of Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva waved to supporters from a motorcade in Brasilia on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The Impact of a U.S. Chip-Making Boom
item.description: Also, North Korea threatens nuclear escalation and Ukraine reinforces its resilience amid a deadly assault.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: A Toxic Stew on Cape Cod: Human Waste and Warming Water
item.description: Climate change is contributing to electric-green algae blooms. Massachusetts wants a cleanup of the antiquated septic systems feeding the mess, but it could cost billions.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Sophie Park
item.media:description: Ashley Fisher, director of the Mashpee Department of Natural Resources in Massachusetts, took samples from the bed of the Mashpee River earlier this month.

item.title: Russian Airstrikes Pummel Ukrainian Civilians
item.description: Ten months into the war, Ukraine has turned the tide in ground combat, but its cities are still facing relentless waves of missiles and exploding drones.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers in Kyiv on Sunday at the site of a missile strike that hit the Ukrainian capital a day earlier.

item.title: Jailed Putin Critics in Russia Offer New Year Messages
item.description: Seasonal greetings from imprisoned opponents offered counterprogramming of a sort to the traditional end-of-year speech from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny at a rally in Moscow in 2020. He has been behind bars since early 2021.

item.title: How to Have a Happier New Year
item.description: Develop stronger relationships in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:description: Times Square yesterday.

item.title: U.S. Pours Money Into Chips, but Even Soaring Spending Has Limits
item.description: Amid a tech cold war with China, U.S. companies have pledged nearly $200 billion for chip manufacturing projects since early 2020. But the investments are not a silver bullet.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark and Ana Swanson

item.title: A New Puzzle Turns Earth Into a Rubik’s Cube, but More Complex
item.description: Continental Drift is one of Henry Segerman’s latest efforts to make mathematics “real.”
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Brett Deering for The New York Times

item.title: North Korea Vows to Escalate Nuclear Threat Against the South
item.description: Kim Jong-un told a Workers’ Party meeting that his country must mass-produce nuclear missiles that could hit South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, center, called for “an exponential increase of the country’s nuclear arsenal.”

item.title: In Bucha, a Final Rampage Served as a Coda to a Month of Atrocities
item.description: Hours before Russian troops began withdrawing from the suburban town, a Russian soldier left a trail of blood and devastated lives in a last paroxysm of violence.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuriy Kryvenko visiting the grave of his father, Oleksandr Kryvenko, who was killed by a Russian soldier in March in Bucha, a suburb of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Russia Bombards Ukraine as Putin Calls Invasion a ‘Sacred Duty’
item.description: Explosions hit the capital, Kyiv, and other cities on the final day of a year shaped by Russia’s invasion. Flanked by soldiers, Vladimir V. Putin called the invasion a “sacred duty” of Russians.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hotel hit by a Russian strike on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: With Benedict’s Death, an Unprecedented Moment for the Modern Church
item.description: Benedict stunned the Roman Catholic world by becoming the first pope in nearly 600 years to resign. Now his death leaves a living pope presiding over the funeral of his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A picture of Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI at a Vatican City shop on Saturday.

item.title: What We Know About the Funeral Arrangements for Pope Benedict XVI
item.description: About 30,000 were expected to visit St. Peter’s Basilica on each of the three days that the pope emeritus’s body would lie in wake there.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Visitors took photos of St. Peter’s Square and Basilica in Vatican City on Saturday. At least 60,000 were expected to visit Rome for the funeral of Benedict XVI.

item.title: Biden and Pelosi Pay Homage to Benedict XVI
item.description: President Biden and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, both Catholic, issued statements mourning the passing of the retired pope.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Stephanie Lai
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden is Catholic, but has had a rocky relationship with the church’s conservative wing.

item.title: India Emerges as Key Global Player Amid Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: The invasion of Ukraine, compounding the effects of the pandemic, has contributed to the ascent of a giant that defies easy alignment. It could be the decisive force in a changing global system.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Hindu ritual on the banks of the Ganges River in Varanasi, northern India. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has chosen Varanasi as a core vehicle of his assertion of India as a Hindu nation, raising tensions with Muslims.

item.title: Pope Benedict XVI Leaves a Spotty Legacy With Sex Abuse Scandal
item.description: His efforts to rid the church of what he called “filth” went further than those of John Paul II, but he was reluctant to hold bishops accountable.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI, left, at a Mass in Sydney, Australia, in 2008, apologized to victims of child sexual abuse by clergy in that country.

item.title: With Speeches to Ukraine, and the World, Zelensky Shapes Narrative of the War
item.description: In a New Year’s Eve addresses to his people , the president delivered a message meant to rouse his people and rally Ukraine’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Ukrainian Presidential Office showing President Volodymyr Zelensky and his wife Olena during their New Year’s address.

item.title: American conservative Catholics mourn Benedict as an unofficial figurehead.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2012, Pope Benedict XVI made Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York a cardinal.

item.title: Mixed Emotions in Germany at Benedict XVI’s Death
item.description: He was the first German pope in over 400 years, but his legacy is marred by failures at handling sexual abuse scandals when he served in southern Germany.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A photo of Benedict XVI was displayed during a service in the Cathedral Church of Our Lady in Munich on Saturday.

item.title: Your Best Advice of 2022
item.description: From readers of The Morning.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Bittersweet First Year for Germany’s New Chancellor
item.description: Olaf Scholz came to power with a mandate for domestic renewal. Instead, he was forced to upend his country’s traditional stance on war and foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz in August in Meseberg, Germany. He was elected on a promise of stability and continuity from the era of his predecessor, Angela Merkel.

item.title: Reporting Vignettes From the Past Year in Canada
item.description: The Times’s journalists in Canada reflect on some of the stories and reporting experiences that marked 2022.
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: North Spirit Lake in October.

item.title: Why Pope Benedict XVI Resigned In 2013
item.description: The resignation of Pope Benedict XVI was the first resignation of a pope in six centuries.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI blessing the faithful in 2013, at the end of his last weekly audience at St Peter’s Square.

item.title: Long before he was pope, the man who became Benedict was a central figure in the church.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI with cardinals in front of St. Peter’s Basilica during his inaugural Mass in 2005.

item.title: Pope Benedict’s Life in Pictures
item.description: Here are a selection of images from Benedict’s long life.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI on a tour of St. Peter’s Square at the end of his inaugural Mass in April 2005.

item.title: Victor Hugo Statue Takes a Prominent Place in France’s Debate on Race
item.description: After a restoration darkened the hue of a statue at the birthplace of the French writer, complaints ensued — then vandalism.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

item.title: Clergymen or Spies? Churches Become Tools of War in Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian officials are cracking down on a branch of the Russian Orthodox Church that they describe as a subversive force doing the Kremlin’s bidding.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: For Palestinians, a Rush to Claim ‘Martyrs’ Killed by Israel
item.description: In one of the deadliest years for Palestinians, a tradition of political and armed groups claiming Palestinian “martyrs” clouds the distinction between civilian and fighter.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amjad Shehedeh next to a portrait of his 15-year-old son, Ahmed, at the family’s shop in Nablus. His son was killed by the Israeli military in November, according to the Palestinian health ministry.

item.title: Benedict XVI, First Modern Pope to Resign, Dies at 95
item.description: He defined a conservative course for the Roman Catholic Church, but his papacy was noted for his struggle with the clergy sexual abuse scandal and for his unexpected resignation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Fisher and Rachel Donadio
item.category: Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI in 2012.

item.title: Zelensky and Putin Set to Address Their Nations
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will share their New Year’s messages as the war grinds on toward its one-year anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Juan Guaidó Is Voted Out as Leader of Venezuela’s Opposition
item.description: The vote to terminate the interim government signaled that members of the opposition had lost faith in Mr. Guaidó’s ability to oust President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Juan Guaidó took the leadership of Venezuela’s opposition in 2019.

item.title: Ukraine Defeats Russian Drone Swarm, as NATO Head Says Kyiv Needs More Arms
item.description: In a war where the vital weapons and tactics have changed repeatedly, Ukraine relies more than ever on air defenses to fend off barrages aimed at its energy systems and cities.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up debris from Russian strikes near Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: They Said They Went to Mali to Keep the Peace. Now They’re Jailed as Mercenaries.
item.description: Ivory Coast said its soldiers were in Mali to provide security for the United Nations peacekeeping mission. But Mali accused them of seeking to undermine its own security.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Mamadou Tapily and Loucoumane Coulibaly
item.category: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Ivorian soldiers supporting the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Mali on parade in Abidjan during the 59th anniversary of Ivory Coast’s independence in 2019.

item.title: In Battered Ukrainian City, the Latest Battle is Against Winter
item.description: Firefighters in Lyman, in Ukraine’s east, contend with land mines, freezing temperatures, damaged buildings, awful cell service and a lack of water.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Yermak and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A firefighter from Emergency Service Department Number 21, the single working fire station in Lyman, Ukraine, extinguishing a fire in an abandoned home this month.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Charged With Human Trafficking and Rape in Romania
item.description: Mr. Tate, an online personality known for making misogynistic comments, and three others will be held in custody for 30 days, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Andrew Tate was escorted outside the headquarters of the Directorate for the Investigation of Organized Crime and Terrorism in Bucharest, Romania, on Thursday.

item.title: Attack on Oil Workers in Eastern Syria Kills at Least 10
item.description: No group claimed responsibility for the assault on a bus convoy. But Islamic State militants remain active in parts of Syria and have increased attacks in the area, which is government-controlled.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Ahead of Major Court Case, E.P.A. Revises Clean-Water Protections
item.description: A new rule revives an older set of protections for rivers, marshes and waterways, setting aside changes in the Obama and Trump administrations that led to years of legal wrangling.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The E.P.A. is taking the action before a Supreme Court decision that could limit the agency’s authority to act in the future.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ checks in with a Russian man who fled the draft.
U.S. Saw Continuing Drop in Murders in 2022
item.description: The situation changed for the better in 2022.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Grand Central Station this year. Murders in large U.S. cities are down more than 5 percent so far this year compared to the same time last year.

item.title: Xi and Putin Meet Again, Two Strongmen in a Weak Moment
item.description: Russia is isolated by its invasion of Ukraine and needs China more than ever. But China, facing a Covid crisis, is in no position to risk sanctions.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia speaking on Friday from Moscow via video with China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
